bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, April 22, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg is afraid that Rankin will excuse himself from the unveiling of the McDowell painting, and so requests that Hench write to him emphasizing the importance of the event.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, April 22, 1942

opener.dateline:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
April 22, 1942

div1.p:
A few minutes ago I received a letter from Dr. Rankin whom, you
know, we had asked to speak at the unveiling of the McDowell paint-
ing at Atlantic City on June 8th. Up until last Monday I had not
heard from him and I called him on the 'phone and received what I
thought was a fairly definite acceptance. In addition he wished
some slight changes which I assured him Mr. Cornwell would be glad
to make in the painting even though we have had some small 4-color
process plates made.

Find attached a copy of Dr. Rankin's letter which came in this morn-
ing as well as a copy of my reply to him. If, in your judgment, it
would be a good thing to do, would you write Dr. Rankin and say that
just incidentally you had heard from me to the effect that he would
speak at the unveiling of the McDowell painting. In your letter
you might assure him that you think the project is worthwhile, if
you feel that it is, and that you feel that he will have a large
and rather important audience.

You will note that in his letter he is afraid that he might be with
the House of Delegates. Mr. Withington and I were in Atlantic City
yesterday and arranged for the use of the Rose Room in the Traymore
Hotel in which the House of Delegates will meet. As a matter of
fact, in my opinion a good percentage of the House of Delegates will
be present at our luncheon.

I suppose that Dr. Rankin does not realize how seriously we take this
affair and I don't want to be the one to scare him out. I would
rather say nothing about that side of it. At the same time, after
having sent out five hundred engraved invitations on which he is men-
tioned as giving the dedicatory address (or whatever it is we shall
call it) we would be in a devil of a fix if he didn't show up. Act-
ually, we are counting on a luncheon for 170 persons. Unlike last
year, we are starting early enough so that we can be sure of the full
number of acceptances.

As you may recall, the unveiling arrangements for “The Conquerors”
at the A.M.A. Convention were made only a few days before the Conven-
tion, and our preparations were inadequate.

Incidentally, as a member of the Pioneers of American Medicine Speak-
ers Club, you and Mrs. Hench will be invited to sit at the speaker's
table.

I will certainly appreciate anything you can do
in this situation to help insure the presence of Dr. Rankin.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
